misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student appears to understand the right-shift algorithm correctly and has implemented it properly.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: This is not a gap - the student's mental model aligns with Java's execution model. The code correctly: (1) stores the last element, (2) shifts all elements one position right, and (3) places the stored element at index 0.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error - the code produces correct output

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that an array right shift with wrap-around requires iterating backwards from the last element (n-1) down to the second element (index 1), assigning the value from the previous index (i-1) into the current index (i), after saving the original last element.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no conceptual gap. The code correctly implements the required array manipulation logic. To perform a cyclic right shift, one must save the element being shifted out (the last element), iterate backwards to prevent overwriting elements before they are used, and finally place the saved element into the now-empty first slot. The student demonstrates a solid understanding of sequential memory manipulation required for array shifts.
